mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 9856911 APPLICATION YJCAT 115853 115853 S0021-9517(24)00566-9 10.1016/j.jcat.2024.115853 The Author(s) Fig. 1 Reaction progress of the reference experiments with P-PPh3-Ru [61] (blue diamonds), P-Ru(PPh3)3 (orange triangles up), Ru(NO)(NO3)3 + TPPTS[a] (black circles), Ru(NO)(NO3)3 [b] (grey squares), BCMBP-Ru (red pentagons), Ru@C[c] (green triangles down) and P-PPh3 (yellow hexagons). Reaction conditions: 300mL Hastelloy autoclave, V(H2O) = 150mL, n(NaHCO3) = 150mmol, m(cat.) = 200mg, p(CO2/H2) = 60bar (1:1), T = 110 °C, t = 5.5h, 700rpm. [a] n([Ru(NO)(NO3)3) = 0.5µmol, n(Trisodium 3,3′,3′′-phosphanetriyltri(benzene-1-sulfonate)) = 1.5µmol. [b] n(Ru(NO)(NO3)3) = 15µmol [c] m(Ru@C) = 50 mg (5 wt%). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 Catalytic recycling experiments of P-PPh3-Ru [61] (blue) and P-Ru(PPh3)3 (orange) over four recycling steps. Kinetic curves of the 1st run (circles), 2nd run (diamonds), 3rd run (triangles) and 4th run (squares). Reaction conditions: 300mL Hastelloy autoclave, V(H2O) = 150mL, n(NaHCO3) = 150mmol, m(cat.) = 200mg, p(CO2/H2) = 60bar (1:1), T = 110 °C, t = 5.5h, 700rpm. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3 Metal loadings (orange diamonds) and catalytic activities (blue bars) of P(2)-PPh3 after the ligand exchange in methanol with different transition metal precursors. Error bars indicate the simple standard deviation of the dually carried out catalytic experiments. Reaction conditions: 40mL Hastelloy autoclave with Teflon inlet, V(H2O) = 5mL, n(NaHCO3) = 5mmol, m(cat.) = 10mg, p(CO2/H2) = 60bar (1:1), T = 110 °C, t = 1h, 1080rpm. [a] Ligand exchange in water. [b] Ligand exchange in tetrahydrofuran. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Variation of (a) the base (n(Base) = 5mmol) and (b) the amount of NaHCO3 in the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formate with P-PPh3-Ru. Error bars indicate the simple standard deviation of the dually carried out catalytic experiments. Reaction conditions: 40mL Hastelloy autoclave with Teflon inlet, V(H2O) = 5mL, m(cat.) = 10mg, p(CO2/H2) = 60bar (1:1), T = 110 °C, t = 1h, 1080rpm. Fig. 5 Variation of (a) the total pressure (CO2/H2 = 1:1) and (b) the partial pressure of H2 (p total = 60bar) in the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formate with P-PPh3-Ru. Error bars indicate the simple standard deviation of the dually carried out catalytic experiments. Reaction conditions: 40mL Hastelloy autoclave with Teflon inlet, V(H2O) = 5mL, n(NaHCO3) = 5mmol, m(cat.) = 10mg, p(CO2/H2) = 60bar (1:1), T = 110 °C, t = 1h, 1080rpm. Fig. 6 Characterization of P-PPh3-Ru [61] (blue), P-dppm-Ru (red), P-dppe-Ru (turquoise), P-dppp-Ru (purple), P-Xantphos-Ru [76] (grey) and P-BINAP-Ru (yellow). (a) ATR-FTIR-spectra: The intensities are normalized to the height of the most intense peak. (b) XRD: The intensities are normalized to the height of the most intense reflex. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 7 Nitrogen physisorption of P-PPh3-Ru [61] (blue diamonds), P-dppm-Ru (red circles), P-dppe-Ru (turquoise triangles down), P-dppp-Ru (purple hexagons), P-Xantphos-Ru [76] (grey triangles up) and P-BINAP-Ru (yellow squares) at 77 K. Filled symbols denote the adsorption, empty symbols denote the desorption. The quantification of the specific surface area (BET) and the total pore volume can be gathered from Table S2. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 8 Catalytic recycling experiments of P-PPh3-Ru [61] (blue), P-Xantphos-Ru [76] (grey), P-BINAP-Ru (yellow), P-dppm-Ru (red), P-dppe-Ru (turquoise) and P-dppp-Ru (purple) over four recycling steps. Graphical abstract Advances in the essential direct hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid are strongly linked to the development of suitable catalytic systems. Here, we have followed the molecular tailoring of macroligands that can be achieved by the crosslinking of aryl phosphine units or of entire transition metal phosphine complexes. Besides the systematic investigation of the reaction parameters, the metal uptake of these macroligands is studied. The versatile crosslinking strategy allows the incorporation of a series of common diphosphines into the frameworks, serving as fixed coordination sites for immobilized ruthenium species. The investigation described here is not restricted to one catalyst, but compares the characteristics and catalytic activities of a wide range of different materials, focusing on their stability over several recycling runs. In particular, catalysts derived from xantphos and BINAP show excellent catalytic performances after a certain induction period. Hence, this study highlights the advantageous properties of rigid bidentate macroligands with spatially close coordination sites for the design of an active and stable solid catalyst in the CO2 hydrogenation to formates. Data availability All data presented in this publication are available from the open access repository Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/doi/10.5281/zenodo.12827336). This sentence is also included in the manuscript. 1 Introduction The valorization of CO2 to formic acid, which is discussed as a liquid hydrogen carrier, non-toxic source of carbon monoxide and represents an important industrial chemical with a growing demand, has challenged chemists for several decades [1–4]. Since the direct hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid is entropically unfavorable and thermodynamically restrained (Δr G θ 298K = 32.9kJmol−1), the integration of deprotonating bases, solvating solvents or esterification agents is often employed, turning the reaction exergonic [2,5]. However, the resulting isolation of the interacting formate causes a high energy demand for downstream processing and sets prerequisites for the design of the crucial catalytic system. The catalytic species should be easily separated from the reaction solution prior to the thermal downstream process in order to inhibit the reverse decomposition of formate at reduced pressures and elevated temperatures [6,7]. Initially, the development of suitable active catalysts was mainly driven by the design of molecular transition metal phosphine complexes [8,9]. Due to their insufficient separability, alternative catalytic approaches were developed, aiming for a heterogeneous nature of the catalyst [10,11]. Starting from classical carbon supported transition metal nanoparticles, the promoting effect of heteroatom doping has been highlighted by several studies, using nitrogen enriched carbon support materials [12–19]. Corresponding to the homogeneous metal phosphine interactions, basic sites of the support stabilize the metal particles and induce pronounced electronic effects on the metal, correlating with enhanced catalytic activities. For a more specific tailoring of the ligating sites and accordingly the electronic properties of the metal, the anchoring of molecular ligand sites on silica materials has bridged the gap between molecular and solid catalysis. This heterogenization strategy on solid surfaces covered the immobilization of amines [20–23], phosphines [23–26], N-heterocyclic carbenes [27,28], bidentate P-N ligands [23,29,30] or pincer ligands [31–33]. The resulting catalysts were active in the synthesis of formates, although they often suffer from a lack of intrinsic stability and require complex multi-step preparation procedures [34]. Instead of covalently binding ligands to a surface, porous organic polymers provide fixed ligand sites that are part of the framework structure. Their preparative versatility enables a tailored formation of functionalized macroligands, echoing the design strategies of molecular catalysis [35–37]. Yang et al. reported the first example of an applicable porous organic polymer, derived from the crosslinked Tröger’s base [38]. However, the ruthenium (Ru)-loaded framework was barely active in the CO2 hydrogenation and required the addition of the molecular triphenylphosphine (PPh3) ligand, resulting in significant leaching issues. Inspired by molecular bidentate phenanthroline complexes, Yoon’s group incorporated this ligand structure into a macroligand and varied the ligating microenvironment of the metal species [39–41]. They embedded heptazine [41], phenantroline [42], NNN pincer [43] or bipyridine units [44,45] into the frameworks, acting as coordination sites for Ru or iridium (Ir) species. The range of nitrogen-functionalized frameworks for CO2 hydrogenation was later extended by studies on melamine-based polymers [46,47], N,P-containing polymers [48] and pyridine-derived covalent triazine frameworks [49], the latter being examined in the continuous hydrogenation of CO2 to methyl formate. Moreover, different N-heterocyclic carbenes have been subjected to incorporation approaches and served as fixed donor centers for Ir complexes [50–54]. Referring to the predominance of soft and strongly ligating phosphines in homogeneous catalysis, polyphosphines have been intensively studied for the immobilization of metal species. Kann et al. investigated the influence of different crosslinked phosphine units on the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation, following an organolithium synthesis route [55,56]. Their work highlighted the advantageous ligating abilities of bidentate macroligands derived from bis(diphenylphosphino)methane (dppm) and 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe) compared to the monodentate PPh3 unit. However, the polymeric analog of dppe exhibited a loss of activity over consecutive recycling runs, which was attributed to structural alterations in the catalytically active metal complex. Subsequently, Gunasekar et al. applied a slightly modified catalytic system in a tubular reactor and demonstrated its stability in the continuous hydrogenation of CO2 to N-N-dimethylformamide. [57] Ji et al. coupled PPh3-based ligating sites with surrounding N sites in order to enrich and activate CO2 in close proximity to the catalytically active Ru center [58]. They prepared frameworks of varying topologies via aldimine condensation and obtained evidence for the beneficial synergy of Ru phosphine species and N species by comparing N-containing and N-absent catalysts. Recently, Hu’s group interconnected the prototypical PPh3 via an external knitting strategy and examined the catalytic activity of the Ru- or Ir-loaded hyper-crosslinked polymers (HCPs) in the CO2 hydrogenation to formate [59,60]. Since the postsynthetic immobilization of the Ir precursor on the polyphosphine did not result in a metal uptake, they carried out direct crosslinking of the entire transition metal phosphine complex. In previous work, we studied this crosslinking approach and investigated systematically the influence of the crosslinking conditions of porous polyphosphines on their catalytic activity and stability in the CO2 hydrogenation to formate [61]. Collectively, the previous works emphasize the crucial role of the macroligands for catalytically active metal centers in the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid. Herein, we investigate the metal uptake of various precursors on the macroligands and compare catalysts, derived from the postsynthetic metalation of crosslinked polyphosphines or the direct knitting of entire metal phosphine complexes. In addition, the versatility of the incorporated phosphine building blocks enables the tailored variation of the ligating microenvironment, revealing its effect on catalytic performance. This systematic exploration of the catalytic system provides insight into the design strategy of stable and active solid catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formate. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Comparison of postsynthetically metalated and directly knitted catalyst Relating to the direct knitting method [62], P-Ru(PPh3)3 was prepared by crosslinking the entire (PPh3)3RuCl2 complex and compared with the reported P-PPh3-Ru [61], which was derived from the postsynthetic metalation of a PPh3-based polyphosphine (Scheme 1 ). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of P-Ru(PPh3)3 reveals aliphatic C-H vibrations (2810cm−1 –2990cm−1) and CH2 deformation vibrations (1373cm−1), originating from alkyl bridges between the aromatic building blocks (Fig. S1 ). The substituted aromatic rings show aromatic skeleton vibrations (1603cm−1) and deformation vibrations (680cm−1 –910cm−1). Additionally, some aromatic C-H vibrations (3053cm−1) coincide with those of the monomeric substrates. The preservation of the C-P vibrations at 1436cm−1 proves the presence of phosphines in the framework structure. Collectively, the respective vibrational modes of the directly knitted P-Ru(PPh3)3 correspond to the spectrum of P-PPh3-Ru, indicating similar framework units and a comparable linking mode of both polyphosphines. However, due to the statistical crosslinking of the aromatic phosphine units, certain differences in the properties of the macroligands are supposed to exist, reducing the uniformity of the respective coordination spheres. X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) confirms the incorporation of PPh3 into the framework (Table S1 ). With respect to the theoretical phosphorus content of an ideally crosslinked polymer, one eighth of the initially applied phosphine amount is part of P-Ru(PPh3)3. This partial fixation within the framework can be attributed to the ability of the aromatic crosslinkers to interconnect among one another, without involving the phosphine [63]. Accordingly, only a fraction of the Ru (1.8 wt% of the applied 7.1 wt%) is loaded on the macroligand, resulting in a molar ratio between phosphine and ruthenium of 1.5:1. Hence, numerically, it appears that the coordination sphere of the molecular ruthenium precursor with three ligating PPh3 (P:Ru = 3:1) is not retained in the solid catalyst. Similar characteristics of the incomplete involvement of PPh3 are observed for P-PPh3-Ru, where every sixth PPh3 monomer is incorporated into the framework. However, a more effective immobilization of the Ru precursor (0.79 wt% of the applied 1.0 wt%) is achieved by postsynthetic metalation of the polyphosphine. The difference in the final metal loadings between the two catalysts is probably due to the limited accessibility of the strongly coordinating, fixed phosphine donor centers in P-PPh3 for the Ru precursor, whereas the Ru species in P-Ru(PPh3)3 can remain associated with the phosphine coordination sphere during crosslinking. The catalysts exhibit similar isotherm shapes (IUPAC Type I and Type IV), indicating a micro- and mesoporous structure (Fig. S2 ). Additionally, both isotherms show a non-closing hysteresis, which is known for non-rigid polymers and can be attributed to pore blocking or swelling effects as well as capillary condensation [64,65]. The pore volume of P-Ru(PPh3)3 in nitrogen physisorption is almost double that of P-PPh3. This difference may be due to the increased incorporation of flexible phosphine units in P-PPh3, diminishing the rigidity required for the formation of a porous structure [61]. This relation is consistent with the findings of Dawson et al. that the porosity of an HCP decreased as the proportion of heteroatom building units in the benzene-based framework increased [66]. The catalysts were examined in the base-mediated hydrogenation of CO2 to formate in the aqueous phase (Scheme 2 ) and referenced to their homogeneous and heterogeneous analogues (Fig. 1 ). The catalytic results highlight comparable productivities for P-Ru(PPh3)3 and P-PPh3-Ru, accompanied by a continuous decrease in catalytic activity over the course of the reaction. Since the reaction rate is not limited by thermodynamic constraints, the flattening of the kinetic curve is presumably due to deactivation of the catalytically active species. Concerning the wettability of the catalyst powders, we observed macroscopically that the HCPs, consisting out of hydrophobic building blocks, floated on the surface of the aqueous phase before catalysis. In contrast, the catalyst powders were finely dispersed after the catalysis, indicating that high pressures and temperatures improve the wettability of the initially hydrophobic materials and presumably allow the aqueous phase to enter the flexible pore system. Regarding reference catalysts, the commercial Ru@C catalyst is inactive, while no significant amounts of formic acid are detected, when the Ru-free polyphosphine P-PPh3 is applied. BCMBP-Ru, consisting of a Ru-impregnated scaffold of internally crosslinked biphenyl units without any involved phosphine centers, is synthesized to examine the role of the fixed phosphine sites. While the aromatic matrix of the BCMBP-Ru framework is structurally identical to P-Ru(PPh3)3 and P-PPh3-Ru, the major difference of BCMBP-Ru is based on the absence of phosphine moieties in the macroligand. The uptake of Ru (w(Ru) = 0.12 wt%) demonstrates a certain interaction between the polymer matrix and the immobilized Ru species. Since BCMBP-Ru shows low acitivity, it appears that both, the Ru species and an available phosphine ligand, are involved and contribute crucially to the formation of the catalytically active species in P-Ru(PPh3)3 and P-PPh3-Ru. Accordingly, the molecular precursor Ru(NO)(NO3)3 slightly catalyzes the hydrogenation of CO2, while the addition of the water-soluble derivative of PPh3 (TPPTS) forms an active homogeneous catalyst. This in situ formed, dissolved Ru catalyst exhibits a comparable activity to the solid P-Ru(PPh3)3 and P-PPh3-Ru, although its deactivation is retarded. Overall, the reference catalysts demonstrate the excellent activity of our heterogenized catalysts and strongly suggest the involvement of ruthenium and phosphine in their catalytically active species. To gain a better understanding of the catalytic stability of P-Ru(PPh3)3 and P-PPh3-Ru, recycling experiments were carried out for four consecutive runs, where the catalyst was reused after exchanging the reaction solution (Fig. 2 ). The continuous deactivation described above results in a significant drop in productivity after 5.5h between the first and second runs. Starting from the third run, the catalysts reach a steady state, while P-Ru(PPh3)3 maintains a slightly higher activity than P-PPh3-Ru. Plausible causes for the observed catalyst deactivation are discussed in the last section of this work. Summarizing the characterization and catalytic data from the comparison of P-Ru(PPh3)3 and P-PPh3-Ru, the method of preparation does not seem to significantly affect the catalytic properties. This outcome is in contrast to the results of Wen et al., who found differences between the post-synthetic metalation and the direct knitting route. They associated the formation of less active metal nanoparticles with the postsynthetic metalation and suggested that direct knitting results in a more active catalyst for the arylsulfonation reaction [67]. Since the different pathways led to barely distinguishable catalysts in the system presented here, we have used the more modular one, the consecutive crosslinking and metalation, for further catalytic investigations of the metal species. Based on the framework P(2)-PPh3 with incorporated PPh3 donor sites, we immobilized different transition metal precursors by ligand exchange from solution. In the immobilization strategy, a molecular ligand of the metal precursor is exchanged with the fixed phosphine macroligand, while the metal species that do not coordinate to the solid macroligand were separated by filtration. Since several precursors were not completely soluble in methanol, we adapted the solvent and used water or tetrahydrofuran (THF), as appropriate. The metal loadings derived from the XRF analysis reveal that negligible amounts of metal coordinate to the polyphosphine, when the ligand exchange is carried out in the aqueous phase (Fig. 3 ). Referring to the hydrophobic aromatic building units, the poor wettability of the macroligand presumably impedes the accessibility of the coordination sites for the dissolved metal precursor. Consequently, the metal species are not coordinatively bound to the solid framework and remain in the filtrate. In contrast, P(2)-PPh3 readily disperses in methanol and THF, resulting in an uptake of metal species onto the macroligand. Concerning the effect of the ligand sphere of the precursor, it is noticeable that applying Ru(acac)3, Pt(acac)2 and Ir(acac)3 leads to a minor metal uptake. This diminished exchange capability can be associated to the bidentate nature of the acetylacetonate ligand. Due to the chelating effect, dissociation of the acac ligand is less likely, impeding the association of a fixed phosphine coordination site. Accordingly, metal precursors with labile ligands such as [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2, [Ir(COD)Cl]2 or [IrCp*Cl2]2 facilitate the ligand exchange and increase the fraction of immobilized metal centers. In general, the metal species involved are not completely taken up by the macroligand, related to the equilibrium nature of the ligand exchange. The resulting catalysts were evaluated in the CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 3), indicating that the residual coordination environment of the immobilized transition metal has a significant effect on its catalytic performance [68]. While platinum-loaded catalysts were inactive, specific ligands promote the activity of Ru and Ir centers, coinciding with studies from the literature [24,56]. In particular, ligand exchange from the precursors [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2 and [Ir(COD)Cl]2 results in active catalysts, while the additional presence of molecular phosphines in (PPh3)3RuCl2 appears to be beneficial for the catalytic application. For the following investigations, the precursor [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2 was used in the catalyst preparation. 2.2 Investigation of the catalytic system In order to gain insight into the catalytic system, we varied several catalytic parameters. Considering the multiphasic reaction system, we initially analyzed the mass transfer characteristics to identify parameters for a microkinetically controlled reaction [69]. Mass transfer from the gas to the liquid phase was excluded at low catalyst amounts (10mg), additionally high impeller speeds (>700 rpm) ensure that the film diffusion limitation is overcome (Fig. S3 ). Due to the flexible properties of the fine catalyst particles and their dynamic swelling ability in the solvated state, a clear prediction about possible pore diffusion limitations cannot be stated. Therefore, low metal loadings were aimed to avoid pore diffusion limitations. The variation of the involved base (Fig. 4 a), which is crucial to turn the thermodynamics of the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid exergonic, reveals the significant role of the chosen base for the catalytic activity. Experiments with ammonia as base show a minor catalytic performance, while the activity increases from NaOH to Na2CO3 to NaHCO3. The promoting effect of NaHCO3 suggests that the reaction mechanism proceeds via the hydrogenation of bicarbonates, which for the other bases originates from the deprotonation of CO2 in aqueous solutions, which has already been discussed in the literature [70,71]. Su et al. found that it is difficult to hydrogenate carbonates to bicarbonates and considered this initial protonation as the rate-limiting step, leading to an enhanced catalytic performance, when bicarbonates were used [72]. In addition, other works have emphasized an increased activity for alkali metal bicarbonates compared to their corresponding carbonates or hydroxides [55,73]. Alkylamines are also capable of generating bicarbonates in aqueous solutions and promoting the CO2 hydrogenation to formate. While the experiments with NEt3 exhibit the second highest activity of the screened bases, the poor miscibility of NPr3 with water presumably inhibits the formation of bicarbonate and the stabilization of the formate. Moderate activities were obtained with the scrubbing amines monoethanolamine (MEA), diethanolamine (DEA) and triethanolamine (TEA). Moreover, the influence of the amount of base is examined, with NaHCO3 as the promoting base (Fig. 4b). The catalytic activities increase with an enhanced NaHCO3 concentration up to 1molL−1 and decrease again with higher NaHCO3 concentrations. A similar behavior has been observed for a homogeneous ruthenium phosphine complex in the hydrogenation of CO2 to formate, suggesting substrate inhibition at the molecular metal center [74]. The use of NaHCO3, most likely acting as a base and substrate, calls into question the role of the gaseous substrates CO2 and H2. The catalytic activity increases continuously with enhanced total pressures (Fig. 5 a), providing a higher concentration of dissolved gas molecules. The variation of the partial pressures at a constant total pressure of 60bar provided more specific insights (Fig. 5b). Firstly, the formate product is already formed in the absence of gaseous CO2, when only H2 is pressurized. This finding supports the above hypothesis that the bicarbonate serves as a feedstock for the hydrogenation reaction. The addition of gaseous CO2 still accelerates the reaction rate, as it shifts the bicarbonate equilibrium and increases the substrate concentration. Secondly, the hydrogenation reaction is mainly dependent on the hydrogen partial pressure. Thus, the highest activity is obtained at a total pressure of 60bar, when 50bar of hydrogen is used. The greater importance of the hydrogen partial pressure is also supported by other works on the base-mediated hydrogenation of CO2 in the aqueous phase, associated with the already increased solubility of CO2 due to the added base [15,75]. 2.3 Variation of the phosphine unit Since the screening of various phosphine ligands revealed the successful properties of bidentate diphosphines for the formation of active homogeneous catalysts, we extended the range of incorporated phosphine building blocks and crosslinked bis(diphenylphosphino)methane (dppm), 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe), 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane (dppp), xantphos [76] and BINAP (Scheme 1) [77,78]. All the resulting polyphosphines exhibit C-P vibrations (1434cm−1) in the FTIR spectra, indicating the presence of phosphine moieties in the insoluble framework (Fig. 6 a). They coincide in the aromatic skeleton vibrations (1481cm−1 and 1584cm−1) and show distinct deformation vibrations of the aromatic C-H bonds (660cm−1 – 760cm−1). Aliphatic C-H vibrations (2820cm−1 – 2980cm−1) suggest crosslinking of the aromatic building units via alkyl bridges, while these are less pronounced for P-BINAP. In general, the frameworks P-dppm, P-dppe and P-dppp, derived from the structurally close Ph2P(CH2) n PPh2 diphosphines, exhibit comparable vibrational patterns. P-Xantphos preserves the structural elements of the monomeric phosphine (Fig. S5 b), referring to the peaks at 2952cm−1 (-CH3) and 1233cm−1 (C-O-C), whereas for P-BINAP the characteristic aromatic deformation vibrational bands (631cm−1 – 822cm−1) of the monomer are retained (Fig. S5 a). The structural elements of the Xantphos and BINAP monomers also appear in the topological conformation of the respective macroligands analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 6b). P-Xantphos and P-BINAP both have HCP-typical amorphous as well as crystalline domains, whose sharp reflexes coincide with those of the monomer (Fig. S4 ). Thus, it seems that the phosphine units are partially arranged in a stacked manner in the slightly flexible polyphosphines, similar to the order of the monomer crystallinity. P-PPh3, P-dppm, P-dppe and P-dppp are XRD-amorphous, but exhibit two very broad reflexes at 2θ of 10° and 21°, suggesting no significant long-range ordered domains. XRF measurements confirm the presence of phosphines in the framework, although only a fraction of the initial amount of phosphine (one-third to one-half) is present in the polyphosphines formed (Table S2 ). As described above, their incomplete incorporation can be associated to the internal crosslinking of the aromatic crosslinker, without involving the phosphine building block. Furthermore, the polymer yield of P-dppm, P-dppe and P-dppp exceeds 100 %, revealing that the solvent 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) is activated for the Friedel-Crafts alkylation and acts as an electrophilic substituent. Owing to its bifunctional structure, it can also contribute to the crosslinking of the aromatic units [61,79]. Regarding the uptake of Ru, the major part of the [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2 precursor coordinates to the fixed diphosphines P-dppm (0.82 wt%), P-dppe (0.76 wt%) and P-dppp (0.90 wt%) after the ligand exchange. P-Xantphos (0.31 wt%) and P-BINAP (0.47 wt%) take up lower amounts of Ru, indicating that a smaller fraction of the diphosphines are accessible or capable of sufficiently coordinating to the metal species. Presumably, the dense stacking of the ordered phosphine units sterically impedes the coordination environment and thus the unhindered immobilization of the molecular Ru complex. According to P-PPh3 (VPore = 0.28mLg−1), P-Xantphos (VPore = 0.18mLg−1) and P-BINAP (VPore = 0.11mLg−1) exhibit a micro- and mesoporosity, which can be attributed to the formation of rigid interconnected frameworks (Fig. 7 ). In contrast, P-dppm, P-dppe and P-dppp show no significant nitrogen uptake, which is related to the absence of porous structures in the dried state. The intrinsic flexibility of their alkyl-bridged diphosphines most probably allows the adaptable arrangement of the building blocks to obtain a close packing of the polymer chains upon removal of the solvent. In addition, the apparent crosslinking by flexible ethylene bridges derived from DCE reinforces this lack of rigidity. Ghafari et al. investigated the effect of different crosslinkers on the porosity and reported that less rigid alkyl units may cause the partial collapse of the framework upon drying, supporting the above hypothesis [80]. However, this finding does not provide any evidence on the porous state under catalytic conditions, as the flexible pores possess swelling abilities in the solvated state, which probably improve the accessibility of the catalytically active species. In the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formate in the aqueous phase, P-Xantphos-Ru showed the highest initial activity (1249 molFA molRu −1h−1) of the different Ru-loaded macroligands (Fig. 8 ). P-BINAP-Ru (1100 molFA molRu −1h−1) and P-dppm-Ru (1049 molFA molRu −1h−1) are comparably active, whereas P-dppe-Ru (624 molFA molRu −1h−1) and P-dppp-Ru (770 molFA molRu −1h−1) show only a slightly improved performance, compared to the monodentate P-PPh3-Ru (536 molFA molRu −1h−1). The catalytic results highlight the advantageous properties of bidentate macroligands, which can improve the ligating ability and increase the electron density at the metal center. Other studies on solid molecular catalysts for the CO2 hydrogenation to formate are in agreement with this promoting effect of multidentate ligands [23,29,56]. Specifically, Graf et al. and Tai et al. showed that the bite angle of diphosphines, which is determined by the length of their alkyl bridge, is a decisive criterion and that small bite angles of diphosphines lead to active metal phosphine complexes [77,78]. Moreover, the covalent fixation of the diphosphines in a crosslinked framework must be considered, which reduces the degree of freedom compared to the molecular ligand. As a consequence, the P-dppe and P-dppp are probably not flexible enough to provide a bidentate coordination to the metal center, whereas the spatially close coordination sites of P-dppm ensure the proximity of the bidentate donor sites even in a stiffened skeleton. According to this relation, the structural rigidity of the BINAP and Xantphos ligands, which is reflected in the porosity formed, enables the multidentate coordination of the Ru species, leading to high initial activities in the CO2 hydrogenation to formate. In X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the overlap of the Ru3d peaks with the dominant C1s peak in combination with the low metal loadings unfortunately does not allow an unambiguous electronic specification of the ruthenium species [76]. Regarding the reaction progress and the consecutive recycling runs, the reaction rates of the catalysts decrease as the catalysis proceeds (Fig. 8). However, the deactivation is reduced and delayed compared to the monodentate macroligand P-PPh3-Ru, presumably referring to the bidentate coordination environment of the solid diphosphines. P-dppe-Ru and P-dppp-Ru, which probably have spatially separated donor centers, are deactivated in the first run, leading to a significant drop in catalytic productivity between the first and second recycling runs. Subsequently, a nearly constant reaction rate occurs in the last two catalytic runs, with P-dppp-Ru showing higher steady-state productivity than P-dppe-Ru. P-dppm-Ru exhibits the highest productivity of all catalysts in the first run (5191 molFA molRu −1 after 5.5h), without any relevant deactivation, as the kinetic curve shows a linear increase over the reaction time. A slight deactivation occurs in the second run, followed by a sharp drop in activity from the second to the third run. Hence, it appears that some degradation of the catalyst occurred during the overnight storage of the catalyst between these two recycling runs. A slight decrease of the reaction rate continues in the third and fourth runs. For P-Xantphos, deactivation occurs continuously during the first and second recycling runs, while the catalytic performance stabilizes in the subsequent runs, exhibiting almost similar reaction rates. P-BINAP shows a comparable induction period, although its high steady-state activity is already reached in the second run. Overall, the examination of the catalytic stabilities suggests the superior properties of rigid bidentate macroligands with spatially close diphosphine centers, leading to active and stable catalysts after a certain induction period. In order to consider the changes in catalytic performance over the multiple recycling steps, we have listed the respective productivities in the first and fourth recycling runs for a better comparison (Table S3 ). Regarding the loss of activity in the recycling experiments, the structural alterations of the catalysts are analyzed. For an in-depth study of a selected catalyst, we refer to the detailed investigation of P-Xantphos [76]. Since we intend to compare the macroligand effects of a wider range of coordination environments in this work, we have not focused on a specific catalyst here. The XRF analysis of the filtrates after the first catalytic runs reveal that only negligible amounts of Ru leached into the reaction solutions (<0.0015 % of the immobilized Ru amount) (Table S4 ). In addition, we carried out an exemplary hot leaching experiment with P-BINAP-Ru, where the catalyst was removed from the hot reaction solution after 2h, the remaining solution was again pressurized with CO2 and H2 and the reaction was continued in the absence of the solid catalyst (Fig. 9 ). Subsequently, no further formate formation was observed. Hence, the leaching of the active species into the liquid phase can be excluded as the origin of catalyst deactivation, proving the heterogeneous nature of the catalysts. FTIR measurements of the pristine and spent catalysts illustrate the structural alterations of the respective catalysts over four recycling runs (Fig. S5 ). Especially P-PPh3-Ru and P-dppp-Ru seem to undergo modifications of the alkyl bridges, as a distinct peak of the aliphatic C-H vibrations (2982cm−1) appears after catalysis. This alteration is probably related to a change in the porous structure, which has been described for HCPs under catalytic conditions [61]. However, it has been shown that a possible loss of HCP porosity does not play a significant role in the initial decrease in catalytic activity. Accordingly, the non-porous macroligands reported here still show high catalytic activities, which is related to their swelling ability in the solvated state. Therefore, it is suggested, that pore-blocking effects or porosity collapse are not the major causes for the deactivation. In the IR spectra of P-dppm-Ru, P-dppe-Ru and P-dppp-Ru, new peaks appear at 1918cm−1 (P-dppm-Ru) and 1928cm−1 (P-dppe-Ru, P-dppp-Ru) after catalysis. These vibrational modes can most likely be assigned to carbonyl ligands, bound to Ru species [81]. Strongly coordinating carbon monoxide has been shown to poison most of the molecular phosphine metal complexes and is considered to cause the deactivation of heterogenized Ru phosphine catalysts [5,55,76]. Hence, the formation of bound carbonyl ligands and the resulting change in the Ru complex seems to be responsible for the deactivation of the solid catalysts. It cannot be determined, whether this poisoning is not pronounced for P-Xantphos-Ru and P-BINAP-Ru or whether the presence of coordinating carbonyl ligands cannot be detected due to the lower amount of Ru sites. In addition, evolved carbon monoxide cannot be detected in the gas phase of the first catalytic run of P-BINAP-Ru (Fig. S6 ). Beside C-O vibration bands (1080cm−1 – 1120cm−1) in all catalysts, the spent polyphosphines exhibit an enhancement of the PO vibrations (1179cm−1) over the catalysis, except for P-Xantphos-Ru. This increased oxidation of phosphines strongly affects the coordinative bond between Ru and the macroligand, reducing the catalytic reaction rate in the CO2 hydrogenation to formate. This oxidation process can be significantly observed for the alkyl-bridged diphosphines P-dppm-Ru, P-dppe-Ru and P-dppp-Ru, while it is less pronounced for the aryl-phosphines P-BINAP-Ru and P-PPh3 and almost absent for P-Xantphos-Ru. In order to evaluate the influence of oxidized phosphines on the catalytic performance, a macroligand analogous to P-PPh3-Ru but consisting of monomeric triphenylphosphine oxide (OPPh3) was synthesized. The resulting catalyst coincides with P-PPh3-Ru in terms of structural elements in the FTIR spectrum (Fig. S7 ). However, only a small amount of Ru is immobilized on the oxidized polyphosphines (0.14 wt%) (Table S1 ), indicating a less likely coordination bond between the oxidized phosphine centers and the Ru species, since sufficient accessibility of the macroligand sites seems to be allowed by an extended porous structure (Fig. S8 ). The catalytic examination of P-OPPh3-Ru emphasizes its low catalytic activity in contrast to P-PPh3-Ru (Fig. S9 ). The exhaustively oxidized P-OPPh3-Ru almost maintains its low catalytic performance over the four recycling runs with minor deactivation. Hence, for the diphosphines discussed above, it appears that the occurring oxidation of the phosphine centers can presumably cause the de-coordination of the metal species from the phosphine site and contribute to the deactivation pathway and thus to the significant losses in reaction rates (Fig. 8). According to the reference experiments with the phosphine-free BCMBP-Ru material (Fig. 1), the de-coordinated Ru species indeed show only low catalytic activities without the interaction with a non-oxidized, ligating phosphine. 3 Conclusion In summary, we have demonstrated the extensive effect of macroligand sites on the catalytic performance of immobilized Ru species. The Ru-loaded polyphosphines, derived from the crosslinking of PPh3 units, exhibited similar catalytic performances in the CO2 hydrogenation to formate, regardless of the compared synthesis pathways. In the immobilization approach, labile monodentate ligands of the metal precursor promote the ligand exchange with the fixed coordination sites, resulting in active heterogenized catalysts. The analysis of the catalytic system revealed that NaHCO3 enhances the hydrogenation reaction, suggesting its role as deprotonating base and actual substrate, while the kinetics are mainly dependent on the H2 partial pressure. Regarding the tailoring of the macroligand, the incorporation of diphosphines drastically increases the catalytic activity and stability of the immobilized Ru species. Spatially close diphosphine ligands seem to allow bidentate coordination, referring to the superior effect of polyphosphines with the building units bis(diphenylphosphino)methane, Xantphos or BINAP. However, P-dppm-Ru suffers from an insufficient stability and a continuous deactivation, whereas P-Xantphos-Ru and P-BINAP-Ru reach steady state activities after a certain induction period. The respective initial degradation can be mainly attributed to oxidation processes of the phosphine centers and the formation of carbonyl ligands that bind to the Ru species and modify the catalytically active complex. coredata.dc:description: Advances in the essential direct hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid are strongly linked to the development of suitable catalytic systems. Here, we have followed the molecular tailoring of macroligands that can be achieved by the crosslinking of aryl phosphine units or of entire transition metal phosphine complexes. Besides the systematic investigation of the reaction parameters, the metal uptake of these macroligands is studied. The versatile crosslinking strategy allows the incorporation of a series of common diphosphines into the frameworks, serving as fixed coordination sites for immobilized ruthenium species. The investigation described here is not restricted to one catalyst, but compares the characteristics and catalytic activities of a wide range of different materials, focusing on their stability over several recycling runs. In particular, catalysts derived from xantphos and BINAP show excellent catalytic performances after a certain induction period. Hence, this study highlights the advantageous properties of rigid bidentate macroligands with spatially close coordination sites for the design of an active and stable solid catalyst in the CO2 hydrogenation to formates.
